description: Demolition of existing properties and redevelopment of the site providing 6x detached dwellings (4x 5 bed and 2x 3 bed units) with associated garages/car ports, parking, internal access road and associated landscaping
decision_conditions: The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on plot 1, details of the proposed carport to serve that plot shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The car port shall then be constructed in accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions, enlargements or alterations as described in Classes A, B or C to Part 1 of Schedule 2 to that Order shall be carried out to any dwellinghouses on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure that the development retains a satisfactory appearance and to ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the following windows shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable and any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale:a. Plot 1i. Pair of windows serving the ensuite, located centrally in the rear elevation at first floor levelii. Dormer window serving the bedroom, located in the northern (flank) roof slopeb. Plot 2i. Pair of windows serving the ensuite, located centrally in the rear elevation at first floor levelii. Rear windows serving the bedrooms, located in the rear roof slopec. Plot 5i. Roof light located centrally in the rear roof sloped. Plot 6i. Roof light located centrally in the rear roof slopeAny film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the measures proposed in Sections 3.3 and 3.4 of Basement Construction and Methodology Statement PM657/18-R02 dated 11 December 2018.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no outbuildings as described in Class E of Part 1 of Schedule 2 to that Order shall be carried out to any dwellinghouses on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the recommendations contained within Section 6 of Preliminary Ecological Appraisal dated February 2019, Section 6 of Bat Survey Report dated May 2019, and the "Conclusions and Recommendations" section of eDNA Survey dated 21 May 2019, shall be implemented in full and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy 7.19 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any excavation or subterranean development, a basement impact assessment and hydrological survey shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The documents shall consider:a. The impact of the development on the risk of flooding, both to the site itself and elsewhere, including any impacts resulting from changes to groundwater flows or ephemeral springsb. The impact of the development on surface water drainagec. The impact of the development on land stabilityReason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be commenced within 3 years of the date of this permission.Reason: To comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

No development shall take place, including any works of demolition, until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:a. Provision for loading/unloading materials.b. Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.c. Temporary site access.d. Signing system for works traffic.e. Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.f. Location of all ancillary site buildings.g. Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.h. Means of enclosure of the site.i. Wheel washing equipment.j. The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitorsk. The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.l. A scheme for recycling/disposing of waste resulting from demolition and  construction works (Major Applications).Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with these approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a detailed landscaping and planting scheme, to include replanting of trees on a two-for-one basis to compensate for those lost as a result of the development, shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Arboricultural Impact Assessment/Statement and Tree Protection Plan" authored by Kim Gifford and dated 28 October 2019. Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

In the period between the commencement and the substantial completion of the development to which this permission relates, any trees on the site which are shown as being retained on the approved plans shall be protected by way of fencing which meets the requirements of BS5837:2005 "Protection of Trees on Construction Sites" (figures 4 and 5). The fenced area(s) shall, at all times, be kept entirely free of vehicles, vehicle movements, equipment and machinery. There shall be no changes to the soil level, no excavation of trenches, no fires lit, and no dumping of toxic chemicals within the fenced areas. No retained trees shall be used for winching purposes. If any retained tree is removed, uprooted, destroyed, dies, or is pruned or damaged in a way which negatively affects the amenity or landscape value of the tree, a replacement tree shall be planted in the same location, the size and species of which may be specified in writing by the council.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on plot 6, details of the foundations of the dwelling on that plot shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates (excluding areas reserved specifically for balconies on the approved plans) shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, details of screening to the balconies of plots 3 and 4 (to prevent any harmful views to the north from plot 3 or to the south from plot 4) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details and plots 3 and 4 shall not be occupied until the approved screening has been implemented in full.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence (excluding works of demolition and site clearance) until a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cycle parking facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level on plot 1, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve that plot shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks the following amendments to planning permission reference: 21/02121/HOU:- Reduction of two-storey rear extension- Changes to fenestration and roof levelThe proposed changes represent minor alterations to the external appearance of the dwelling, including reduction to the scale of the two-storey rear extension and reconfiguration of the arrangement of the rooflights and solar panels on the roof of the front elevation.The proposed alterations would see the middle section of the proposed rear extension at first floor level removed altogether.The rear extension at first floor would otherwise remain unchanged. The removal of the mid-section of the first floor rear extension would necessitate some internal reconfigurations to the accommodation including repositioning of an en-suite and removal of a side-facing window formerly serving an ensuite to the side and externally would result in the change from a central pitched gable feature to a central dormer with timber cladding. The mid-section of the ground floor rear extension would be fitted with a roof lantern and the existing dormer to the first floor at the rear would be retained with timber clad to match existing elevational treatment. One rooflight to the rear would be reduced in size but be retained in the position as originally approved. To the front elevation, the proposals include a reconfiguration of the arrangement of the rooflights and solar panels on the roof of the front elevation.Officers consider the proposals would not result in a material harmful effect on the character and appearance of the dwelling or original design intent, nor have a detrimental impact to the amenity afforded to the future occupants. Officers are similarly satisfied that the proposed amendments would not give rise to any material issues in terms of character and appearance of the development from the streetscene or to neighbouring amenities. Accordingly, the proposed amendment is considered to be non-material and it is recommended that the application be granted.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single-storey rear extension with installation of 4no solar panels and associated changes to fenestrationConsultation10 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on Flooding; and,- The impact of the development on Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officer Comment:  With regards to neighbouring amenity, the principal properties to be considered are No. 30 and No. 34 Hardman Road. Policy Guidance 33 (Single Storey Rear Extensions)of the Residential Design SPD states that single storey rear extensions should be designed so that they appear proportionate and subordinate to the host building. In all cases, the following guidance applies:-If the neighbouring property has a different rear building line, then the depth of the extension could be increased.-In all cases, at least 50% of the rear garden should remain.-Extensions should generally not exceed 3m to 3.5m in depth.-Extensions with a flat roof should not exceed 3m in height.-Extensions with a parapet roof should not exceed 3.3m in height.-Extensions with a pitched roof should not exceed 4m in height.No. 30 Hardman Road has already been extended as has No. 36. This would usually allow for an extension to exceed 3.5m in depth. However, with regards to No. 34 Hardman Road, officers note that this property does not benefit from a rear extension. It is noted that the applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the closest ground floor principal habitable room window or No. 34 Hardman Road in terms of daylight/sunlight. Given that scale of the extension and the proximity of neighbouring widows it is considered that there is a likelihood that the development would breach the "45 Degree Rule" and reduce light entering into the neighbouring window, which in turn would harm the residential amenities of the occupant of the neighbouring property. As such, the proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.The applicant is advised to resubmit with sufficient evidence to demonstrate that Policy Guidance 17 and 33 of the RBK Residential Design guide has been taken into account.  https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/file/102/residential-design-spdAnother material planning consideration is the provision of adequate amenity space for both existing and future occupants. Officers note that the property already benefits from a large outbuilding to the rear of the garden. The proposed rear extension would further reduce the remaining amenity space to below current external amenity standards.Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The Flood Risk Form submitted by the applicant indicates that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: No Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021). Therefore, it has not been demonstrated that the proposals would achieve the highest standards of fire safety.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a single storey full width rear extension following the demolition of an existing rear and side extension.ConsultationNo representations have been received in response to the public consultation.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Whilst not strictly following the guidance in the SPD, the proposed development is considered to nonetheless be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Given the size of the plot coupled with the distance from boundaries It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire Safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Consultations: Neighbour notifications: No representations have been received. Historic England: Authorise delegated determination. No views expressed on the proposal.Historic England (Archaeology): Authorise delegated determination. No views expressed on the proposal.Kingston Town CAAC: Objection on basis of the tile banding to the foot of the shop unit.Officer Comments: Noted. Please see body of this report for full assessment.Site and Surroundings The application building comprises of a two-storey building. The application pertains to the ground floor commercial unit. The site is located within the designated Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The building that the advertisement is to be displayed on is a statutorily Grade II Listed Building. Proposal This listed building consent application seeks consent for shopfront alterations, removal of fascia boxing and replace with new traditional one, replace door with glazing timber frame and painted soft blue, rounded moulding decorations and ceramic band aggregated to timber stall riser and pilaster skirtings.  It is noted that separate applications for advertisement consent and full planning permission have been submitted to the Local Planning Authority (application reference: 22/01055/ADV and 22/01382/FUL). Planning Considerations The key planning considerations in this case are: - The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area (including heritage impact); and- The impact of the development on highway safety Character and Appearance / Impact upon Heritage AssetsThe NPPF states that the creation of high quality buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve. Good design is a key aspect of sustainable development, creates better places in which to live and work and helps to make development acceptable to communities. Planning decisions should ensure that developments: will function well and add to the overall quality of the area; are visually attractive as a result of good architecture, layout and appropriate and effective landscaping; are sympathetic to local character and history; and establish a strong sense of place. Permission should be refused for development of poor design that fails to take opportunities available for improving the character and quality of an area and the way it functions, taking into account and local design standards or style guides in plans or supplementary planning documents. Conversely, where the design of a development accords with clear expectations in plan policies, design should not be used by the decision-maker as a valid reason to object to development. At the regional level, the London Plan requires that development have regard to the form, function and structure of an area, place or street, as well as the scale, mass and orientation of surrounding buildings. It should improve an area's visual or physical connection with natural features. In areas of poor or ill-defined character, development should build on the positive elements that can contribute to establishing an enhanced character for the future function of the area. Architecture should make a positive contribution to a coherent public realm, streetscape and wider cityscape. It should incorporate the highest quality materials and design, appropriate to its context. Accordingly, the Core Strategy states the Council's intention to protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, its existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. The Council will seek opportunities for sensitive enhancement in these areas and in areas of poorer environmental quality, where character has been eroded or needs improving. The assessment of development proposals will be guided by the Borough Character Study and the Residential Design SPD, ensuring that new development: - Recognises distinctive local features and character - Has regard to the historic and natural environment - Helps enhance locally distinctive places of high architectural and urban design quality - Accords with neighbourhood "strategies for delivery" set out under "Character, Design and Heritage" - Relates well and connects to its surroundings The most essential elements identified as contributing to the character and local distinctiveness of a street or area which should be respected, maintained or enhanced include the following: - Prevailing development typology, including housing types, sizes and occupancy - Prevailing density of the surrounding area- Scale, layout, height, form (including roof forms) and massing - Landscape setting and features - Plot width and format, which includes spaces between buildings - Building line build-up, set-back and front boundary - Typical details and key features such as roof forms, window format, building materials and design detailing of elevations, existence of grass verges, etc. The Council's Residential Design SPD provides further in-depth guidance. Policy Guidance 29 (Materials and Detailing) states that: - Developers will be expected to demonstrate that they have considered the choice of materials and design detailing of those buildings that they consider represent the prevailing character of the streetscene or local area. - A preference should be given to the use of prevailing materials and details used in the surrounding local area unless it can be demonstrated that the choice of materials or use of design features in a proposal for residential development would enhance the character and appearance of the streetscene. - Care should be taken to ensure the replication of detailing or materials present in the street scene of local area represents an authentic synthesis of local architectural styles that compliment those of the host building or surrounding area. Development proposals which include the use of materials or detailing which is out of context or is lacking in imagination or character will be discouraged. NPPF provisions: It is one of the core principles of the NPPF that heritage assets should be conserved in a manner appropriate to their significance. Chapter 16 of the National Planning Policy Framework, 2021 at para 195 sets out that the local planning authority should identify and assess the particular significance of any heritage asset... They should take this assessment into account when considering the impact of a proposal on a heritage asset, to avoid or minimise conflict between the heritage asset's conservation and any aspect of the proposal. Paras 194-198 sets out the framework for decision making in planning applications relating to heritage assets and this application takes into account the relevant considerations in these paragraphs. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policy 1.1 of the Council's Adopted Development (or Core) Strategy, (Core Strategy), and policy 7C of the Council's Adopted Development Management Development Plan Document, (DPD), seek to ensure that new development conserves the significance of heritage assets. Development should be sympathetic in its materials and architectural detailing and the introduction of designs or materials which undermine the significance of heritage assets should be avoided. More broadly, policies D4 and D8 of the London Plan 2021 collectively seek to ensure that new development is informed by and complements its surroundings. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Historic England's listing record sets out (NO. 8a, together with No's 6 and 8 Church Street): "Late C16 or early C17. Originally a public house, divided into three shops in the later C19. Two storeys, three bays wide. Timber framed with jettied upper floor. Modern shop fronts on the ground floor. Square headed sash windows to two left hand bays. Other modern oriel. The upper floors rendered in the C19. No.6 also has some C20 false timbering and a modern oriel bay window. Tiled roof with chimney stack between Nos. 6 and 8."The Council's Supplementary Planning Document titled, "Shopfronts and Shopsigns" (2005) provides guidance on signage for historic buildings. The SPD for shopfronts and shopsigns states "any illuminated fascia sign on historic buildings should preserve the character and appearance of the building and area. Effective and acceptable forms of illuminations are those where the light fitting is concealed and include: tubes encased in trough housings, uplighters or downlighters which should be carefully located so that the spread of light is controlled and not overbright; or internally-illuminated individual letters or characters in the form of tubes encased with a translucent face and solid/opaque sides or vice versa, or solid characters raised with tubes beneath to create a 'halo' effect." The application proposes the removal of the existing fascia boxing and replacement with traditional fascia. Officers consider this to be a positive improvement given that the existing box fascia is an overly deep, incongruous feature to the building and wider street scene. The shopfront will be largely retained, keeping the same structure with a door to the right hand side and a timber-framed glazed window to the left. The existing door is proposed to be replaced with a full height timber framed door. The shopfront is proposed to be painted soft blue (i.e. Farrow and Ball Lulworth No.89) and a linear band of black and white ceramic tiles is proposed to the foot of the shop unit. Officers note the objection raised by Kingston Town CAAC with regards to the ceramic tiling with comments that this element of the proposals is out of keeping with the conservation area. Officers do not consider that the ceramic tiling is of an extent or design so as to constitute material harm or difference to the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area in terms of its visual impact, and the ceramic tile banding is found in this instance to appropriately tie in with the overall design intent of the proposed shop unit refit. The proposals also include the installation of fascia signage to the front elevation and the addition of a projecting sign. The proposed fascia sign would comprise of individually fixed black acrylic 3D letters and clear acrylic sides internally illuminated at a level of 350 cd/m2 and the proposed projecting sign would comprise of a white painted square metal sheet with three rows of powder coated aluminium black glasses as commercial logo.The new advertisements are considered appropriate in their style, form and design given the heritage setting and designation of the application site. The signage is considered to be of a good-quality which is not considered to harmfully impact upon the character of the area within the designated Kingston Old Town Conservation Area, nor result in harm to visual amenity or the appearance and special interest of this Grade-II listed building. Highway SafetyThe NPPF requires that in assessing applications for development, it is ensured that: appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport modes can be - or have been - taken up; safe and suitable access to the site can be achieved for all users; and any significant impacts from the development on the transport network (in terms of capacity and congestion), or on highway safety, can be cost effectively mitigated to an acceptable degree. Development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe. Local Planning Authorities are expected to have regard to its effect upon the safe use and operation of any form of traffic or transport on land (including the safety of pedestrians), on or over water, or in the air. Public safety considerations, the second arm of control over advertisements, do not arise very frequently. However, when it can be shown that signs would be confused with traffic signals or the visibility of drivers is impaired, a solid and sustainable ground for refusal of Advertisement Regulation consent is provided. The proposed projecting advertisement would not be illuminated, however the fascia signage would be illuminated to 350cd/m2. It is considered given the level of illuminance and position of the building in a pedestrianised zone of the town centre that it would not result in a distraction to highway users and would not prejudice highway safety. The proposed signage is therefore in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy. Conclusion The proposed development would provide for the display of advertisements to the ground floor commercial unit at 8A Church Street, Kingston. It is considered that the proposed signage and shopfront alterations are acceptable resulting in no material harm to the character and appearance of the designated Grade-II listed building, nor on the wider Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The proposals would not have any material effect on highway safety. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed development would be in accordance with paragraph 200 of the NPPF 2021, policies D4 and HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. The proposal would be acceptable and would preserve the character and appearance of the Grade-II Listed Building and Conservation Area, having due regard to Section 16 of the Planning (Listed Building and Conservation Area) Act 1990 permission should be granted. Furthermore, it is concluded that the proposal would not harm the heritage asset as per the requirements of the NPPF 2021.Recommendation That listed building consent should be GRANTED.

The site comprises a terraced dwelling.6x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and one representation has been received, highlighting support for the application.Planning History10/12821/HOU- Erection of a single storey rear extension with rooflights- GRANTED 16.02.2011ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development;The impact upon heritage assets; The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,The impact on the public highway.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Note: The application includes the erection of a front porch extension. The proposed porch would project 1.5 metres to the front of the dwelling and is of a similar design to the existing porch at no.19 Cardinal Avenue. Officers consider the proposed development, would have no detrimental impact on the character and appearance of the streetscene, host property, or the surrounding area.Non- Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 194 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The site comprises a terraced dwelling, located in the Tudor Estate Area of Special Character. The application site is not in a conservation area, but is within an area of special local character. The host building is therefore is not a heritage asset but a non-designated heritage asset.Paragraph 203 of NPPF applies to non-designated heritage assets and it is stated in this paragraph that:-"The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset."As noted above, officers consider that the proposed development would not result in material harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore in accordance with policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officers Note: The application includes the erection of a front porch extension. would cause no significant increase in loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties at no.19 or no.23 Cardinal Avenue.Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would include the construction of a porch to the front of the property. However, the existing hardstanding to the front of the dwelling would still be sufficient to accommodate one space for on-site parking. The PTAL for this part of Cardinal Avenue, is 1b. Taking into account the maximum car parking standards set out in the London Plan, which are up to 1.5 spaces per dwelling, for an Outer London PTAL 1 - 2, 3+ bedroom dwelling, it is considered that this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal, given that it is reflective of the existing situation.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a flat within a detached property. The site is located within Riverside North Conservation Area.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 4 objections were received, but 2 were not received within the statutory consultation period. The 2 objections received within the statutory consultation periods relate to:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inappropriate design/layout- NoiseThe concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.Kingston Town CAAC - Objection (Objection. We objected to the recent alterations to 1 Albany Mews, next door in this detached block of four flats. However, those alterations are minor & partially screened from public view by landscaping compared to this planning application. The application, including its extended porch, wrap around bay, front dormer & other new windows, would overwhelm the host property, jar with its neighbours all of which remain largely in their original state, be clearly visible from the public highway & detract significantly from the character & appearance of the conservation area. It should therefore be refused.)The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed front/side wraparound extension would not strictly comply with the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth, however it would have a modest height, appropriate roof form and materiality to match the existing property, and as such officers consider that it would appear a proportionate and appropriate addition to the host property. Officers note that the Kingston Town CAAC has objected to the proposal based on the uniformity of the block of 4 flats. While this objection is noted, officers note that the proposed extension has been designed to appear in keeping with approved application ref: 20/00155/HOU on the adjoining property No. 3 Albany Mews. While 3 Albany Mews does have a more limited impact on the streetscene, officers consider that the proposal would appear very subordinate and would not overwhelm the host property or detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area.In terms of design, Officers acknowledge that the proposed development would deviate from the original design of the wider block, however, the proposal is sympathetic to the original design and other permitted extensions. As such, overall the development would not harm the character of the host property nor would it harm the character of the wider area. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the subordinate nature of the proposed development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. As the proposal would seek to provide a minor residential extension to the existing residential accommodation officers consider that there would be no material increase in noise or disturbance for the occupiers of neighbouring properties. Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk form states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).HeritageSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 194 to 203 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as a linear area whose form and mature landscape is influenced by the River Thames, alongside which lie ancient riverside estates, important 19th century public works that established Canbury Gardens, a group of large Victorian/Edwardian houses and late Victorian boathouses fronting the river.As noted above, officers conclude that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Riverside North Conservation Area, but rather preserve it. As previously mentioned, the proposed development would be in keeping with host property and as such would maintain the character of the immediate surrounding area. Given no harm to heritage assets has been identified in this case, it is not necessary to weigh up the proposals against any public benefits.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the represenations have been carefully considered, however, overall Officers conclude that the proposed development would be in general accordance with the, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a substantial two storey detached residential dwelling and is located within the Southborough Conservation Area- a designated heritage asset.ProposalPlanning permission is sought for the erection of single-storey side/rear extension including replacement of existing front side extension roof and associated changes to the fenestration.This proposal follows an earlier scheme (21/03744/HOU) which was refused for the following reasons:The applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed development would preserve or enhance the Southborough Conservation Area and would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling, or the surrounding area and would not result in less than substantial harm to the significance of the Southborough Conservation Area. The proposed development would therefore conflict with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended), Paragraph 202 of the NPPF 2021, Policies D3 and HC1 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD, 2013.The applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed first floor side extension would comply with BRE Guidance in relation to the ground floor habitable rooms in the eastern elevation of No. 51 Woodlands Road and would not result in in an unacceptable loss of daylight and or sunlight and that the raised patio area would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the same neighbouring occupiers in terms of privacy and outlook. The proposed development would therefore result in an unacceptable adverse impact on the amenities of this neighbouring occupier, contrary to Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy 2012.Officers note: This proposal is supported with a Heritage Statement and compliance with the BRE guidance has been demonstrated on the submitted drawings, in relation to both neighbouring properties at Nos. 51 and 55 Woodlands Road.Consultation 20 properties were notified of the proposal. Two representations were received in support of the proposal.Surbiton Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee (CAAC): No response.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area and heritage assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. Character and Appearance and HeritageParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals affecting heritage assets, and their settings, should conserve their significance, by being sympathetic to the assets' significance and appreciation within their surroundings. The cumulative impacts of incremental change from development on heritage assets and their settings should also be actively managed. Development proposals should avoid harm and identify enhancement opportunities by integrating heritage considerations early on in the design process.Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed ground floor side extension by way of its siting would not be visible from the street and is of an acceptable scale and depth, with a pitched roof and materials to match the existing garage. It would also be in alignment with the existing garage.To the rear the proposed extension would also be modest in scale and depth, setback from the property boundaries with a flat roof and large glazed windows and doors to the side and rear elevations.  Sufficient detail has been submitted regarding the proposed window to the rear which would be of a different design to those on the front elevation and would be in keeping with the host dwelling and surrounding Conservation Area and would not result in any harm to the significance of a designated heritage asset.To the front of the property it is proposed to change the two existing pitched roof elements of the single storey structure, to a flat roof form and to convert the existing single garage and study into two garages which would feature a large garage door which are considered acceptable. The heritage statement specifies the use of traditional brickwork and use of other appropriate mat external materials for the garage door and fenestration in keeping with the host dwelling, surrounding Conservation Area and would not result in any harm to the significance of a designated heritage asset.The proposed first floor extension would be set back from the main front elevation, and the ground floor below, with a roof form and fenestration to match the host dwelling. This aspect of the proposed development would appear both proportionate and subordinate when viewed from the streetscene. It is considered that sufficient details have been provided in relation to the fenestration changes to the front elevation.Having regard to the above, it is considered that the proposed development would preserve and enhance the Southborough Conservation Area and would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling, the surrounding area and would result in less than substantial harm to the significance of the Southborough Conservation Area. The proposed development is therefore in accordance with Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended), Paragraph 202 of the NPPF 2021, Policies D3 and HC1 of the London Plan 2021, Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD, 2013.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed scale and siting of the proposed development at ground floor level are considered to have an acceptable impact on neighbouring properties, as would the proposed changes to the front elevation in terms of fenestration details and roof design. Officers note that although glazing is proposed to the side elevation of the proposed rear extension, there is an existing conservatory in this location and the impacts would be no greater than the current situation. The proposed first floor side extension would be modest in scale, and compliance with BRE Guidance has been demonstrated in relation to the ground floor habitable rooms in the eastern elevation of No. 51 Woodlands Road with regards to daylight and or sunlight. The proposed development would therefore result in an acceptable impact on the amenities of this neighbouring occupier, in accordance with Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy 2012.Although the proposal would introduce new windows to the ground floor side elevation, these would be sufficiently setback from the site boundary to No.51 Woodlands and further screened by the existing boundary treatment. A condition will ensure appropriate boundary treatment is retained to this area of the site.  Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, there is sufficient space for provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
